description: From Middle English fluid, from Latin fluidus (“flowing; fluid”), from Latin fluō (“to flow”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰleh₁- (“to swell; surge; overflow; run”). Akin to Ancient Greek φλύειν (phlúein, “to swell; overflow”). Not related to English flow, which is a native, inherited word from *plew-.

adjectives.description: fluid (comparative more fluid, superlative most fluid)

entries.meaning: (not comparable) Of or relating to fluid.
In a state of flux; subject to change.
Moving smoothly, or giving the impression of a liquid in motion.

examples: “Oh, Loki made sure of that. My mortal parents blamed him for the way I was, for being fluid.”

entries.meaning: Any substance which can flow with relative ease, tends to assume the shape of its container, and obeys Bernoulli's principle; a liquid, gas or plasma.
A liquid (as opposed to a solid or gas).
(specifically, medicine, colloquial, typically in the plural) Intravenous fluids.
